definition:
The space curve traced out by the parameterization
$${\boldsymbol{\gamma}}(t)=\left[\begin{array}{c}a \cos(t)\\ a\sin
    (t)\\ bt\end{array}\right],\quad t\in {\mathbb{R}},\; a,b\in{\mathbb{R}}$$
is called a *circular helix* (plur. [*helices*]{}).

Its Frenet frame is: $$\begin{aligned}
  {\mathbf{T}}&= \frac{1}{\sqrt{a^2+b^2}} \begin{bmatrix} -a\sin t \\
  \hphantom{-}a\cos t \\b\end{bmatrix}\,,\\
  {\mathbf{N}}&= \begin{bmatrix} -\cos t \\ -\sin t \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}\,,\\
  {\mathbf{B}}&= \frac{1}{\sqrt{a^2+b^2}} \begin{bmatrix} \hphantom{-}b\sin t \\
  -b\cos t \\ a\end{bmatrix}\,.\end{aligned}$$ Its curvature and torsion
are the following constants: $$\begin{aligned}
  \kappa = \frac{a}{a^2+b^2}\,, \quad
  \tau = \frac{b}{a^2+b^2}\,.\end{aligned}$$

A circular helix can be conceived of as a space curve with constant,
non-zero curvature, and constant, non-zero torsion. Indeed, one can show
that if a space curve satisfies the above constraints, then there exists
a system of Cartesian coordinates in which the curve has a
parameterization of the form shown above.

![A plot of a circular helix with $a = b = 1$, and
$\kappa = \tau = 1/2$.](helix2.eps)

An important property of the circular helix is that for any point of it,
the angle $\varphi$ between its tangent and the helix axis is constant.
Indeed, if we consider the position vector of that arbitrary point, we
have (where $\mathbf{k}$ is the unit vector parallel to helix axis)
$$\begin{aligned}
\frac{d{\boldsymbol{\gamma}}}{dt}\cdot\mathbf{k}=\begin{bmatrix} -a\sin t \\
\hphantom{-}a\cos t \\ b \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 0\; 0\; 1\end{bmatrix}=b
\equiv \bigg\lVert\frac{d{\boldsymbol{\gamma}}}{dt}\bigg\rVert\cos\varphi=\sqrt{a^2+b^2}\cos\varphi.\end{aligned}$$
Therefore, $$\begin{aligned}
\cos\varphi=\frac{b}{\sqrt{a^2+b^2}} \text{constant},\end{aligned}$$ as
was to be shown.

There is also another parameter, the so-called *pitch of the helix* $P$
which is the separation between two consecutive turns. (It is mostly
used in the manufacture of screws.) Thus, $$\begin{aligned}
P=\gamma_3(t+2\pi)-\gamma_3(t)= b(t+2\pi)-bt=2\pi b\,,\end{aligned}$$
and $P$ is also a constant.
